THE Prime Minister stated that he, Lord Curzon, and theThe Composition of Chief Secretary for Ireland had seen Mr. T. P. 0'Connor andthe Convention. Colonel Craig, and had placed before them a scheme for theConvention, drawn up on the assumption that it should be a small body of about sixty members. Mr. T. P. 0'Connor had pointed outthat he was not authorised to approve the scheme, and it was then decided to telegraph fully to Messrs. Redmond, Dillon, and Devlin,asking for their opinion on the scheme. A joint reply had been^ received from Messrs. Dillon and Devlin stating that it was absolutely' unacceptable, that no statement should be made inParliament to-day, and that they were writing fully. It was probable that the telegram had not reached Mr. Redmond until very early this morning.Printed for th.c War Cabinet May 1.917 The Prime Minister stated that he intended to write a letter toMr. T. P. 0'Connor expressing the War cabinet's surprise at theabsence from London at this juncture of the Irish Leaders. It was understood that Mr. Redmond was absent through illness.The War Cabinet decided that In the circumstances the proposed statement to the House ofCommons must be postponed.2. The War Cabinet further discussed certain minor pointsconnected with the composition of the Convention. It was thoughtpreferable, in the case of labour representatives, to approach thechief industries directly, and not through the Trades Councils.3. Lord Curzon stated that he had received a letter from lord Midleton saying that his supporters and, he also thought,the Ulster Unionists would not come into the Convention unless thediscussion of an Leland independent of the Empire were barredfrom the outset.The Chancellor of the Exchequer pointed out that in a reply to questions in the House of Commons on the 24th May he hadreminded the House of the Prime Ministers statement that it mustbe a question of self-government within the Empire.The general view of the War Cabinet was that it was undesir-able to exclude the Sinn Feiners from the Convention, even though some of them held extreme views. It was recognised that their presence might have advantageous reactions on the other partiespresent, and in the event of their being present it seemed undesir-able to prohibit them from expressing their views, however extremethese might be. It was decided to invite Lord Midleton to attend ameeting of the War Cabinet in order to express his views.The Publication ofMercantile losses from Submarines.4. The War Cabinet further considered the question of makinga public statement "on the relation of submarine losses to the food supply, and decided that Any statements made should be on the lines set forth in minute 4 of War Cabinet 145.Political Aims ofthe Allies.Anglo-french conference.5. The Prime Minister called attention to a telegram fromSir George Buchanan conveying a suggestion of M. Kerensky thatthere should be a fresh discussion of the political aims of the Allies.The War Cabinet decided To raise the question at the forthcoming Anglo-french conference.6. The War Cabinet requested Lord Robert Cecil to arrange for the postponement of theAnglo-French Conference to Monday, 28th May.Eeport of the 7.
